title: Nathan Fillion’s ‘Not Nice’ Guy Gardner to Appear in HBO’s Lanterns Series
description: It appears that Nathan Fillion’s Guy Gardner will fare much better than his T.D.K. did. Fillion’s “jerk” of a Green Lantern, who will make his debut in James Gunn’s Superman movie this July 11, will also appear in HBO’s Lanterns series, THR and others reported on Monday. Production on Lanterns began Feb. 27. Fillion recently […]
author: Matt Webb Mitovich
excerpt: Nathan Fillion's Guy Gardner will appear on HBO's 'Lanterns' series after debuting in 'Superman' this summer.
text: It appears that Nathan Fillion‘s Guy Gardner will fare much better than his T.D.K. did. Fillion’s “jerk” of a Green Lantern, who will make his debut in James Gunn’s Superman movie this July 11, will also appear in HBO’s Lanterns series, THR and others reported on Monday. Production on Lanterns began Feb. 27. Fillion recently described Guy to TVGuide.com as a “jerk” and “not nice, which is very freeing as an actor because you just think to yourself, ‘What is the most selfish, self-serving thing I can do in this moment?’ And that’s the answer…. I think if he has a superpower, it might be his overconfidence.” Because it certainly isn’t hair hairstyle. Friday Night Lights alum Kyle Chandler will headline the DC Studios production as Hal Jordan, alongside onetime Krypton resident Aaron Pierre as John Stewart. Other previously announced castings include Kelly Macdonald (Boardwalk Empire) as Sheriff Kerry, a “no-nonsense woman deeply devoted to her family and close-knit town”; Ulrich Thomsen (The Blacklist, Banshee) as the villainous Sinestro, “a former Green Lantern who turned rogue” whose “manipulative nature drives his enduring obsession with his former mentee, Hal Jordan”; Poorna Jagannathan (The Night Of) as Zoe, who is described as “every bit as composed and cunning of the influential men around her”; and Jason Ritter as Billy Macon, “a good-looking charmer who does his father’s (Raising Hope‘s Garret Dillahunt) bidding.”  Described by DC Studios co-CEO Peter Safran as being “very much in the vein of True Detective,” Lanterns will follow new recruit John Stewart and legend Hal Jordan, two intergalactic cops drawn into a dark, Earth-based mystery as they investigate a murder in the American heartland. Want scoop on Lanterns, or for any other DC TV show? Shoot an email to InsideLine@tvline.com, and your question may be answered via Matt’s Inside Line!
html:
It appears that Nathan Fillion‘s Guy Gardner will fare much better than his T.D.K. did.

Fillion’s “jerk” of a Green Lantern, who will make his debut in James Gunn’s Superman movie this July 11, will also appear in HBO’s Lanterns series, THR and others reported on Monday.

Production on Lanterns began Feb. 27.

Fillion recently described Guy to TVGuide.com as a “jerk” and “not nice, which is very freeing as an actor because you just think to yourself, ‘What is the most selfish, self-serving thing I can do in this moment?’ And that’s the answer…. I think if he has a superpower, it might be his overconfidence.”

Because it certainly isn’t hair hairstyle.

Friday Night Lights alum Kyle Chandler will headline the DC Studios production as Hal Jordan, alongside onetime Krypton resident Aaron Pierre as John Stewart.

Other previously announced castings include Kelly Macdonald (Boardwalk Empire) as Sheriff Kerry, a “no-nonsense woman deeply devoted to her family and close-knit town”; Ulrich Thomsen (The Blacklist, Banshee) as the villainous Sinestro, “a former Green Lantern who turned rogue” whose “manipulative nature drives his enduring obsession with his former mentee, Hal Jordan”; Poorna Jagannathan (The Night Of) as Zoe, who is described as “every bit as composed and cunning of the influential men around her”; and Jason Ritter as Billy Macon, “a good-looking charmer who does his father’s (Raising Hope‘s Garret Dillahunt) bidding.” 

Described by DC Studios co-CEO Peter Safran as being “very much in the vein of True Detective,” Lanterns will follow new recruit John Stewart and legend Hal Jordan, two intergalactic cops drawn into a dark, Earth-based mystery as they investigate a murder in the American heartland.

Want scoop on Lanterns, or for any other DC TV show? Shoot an email to InsideLine@tvline.com, and your question may be answered via Matt’s Inside Line!
